items: High Honors in Stuyvesant Computer Science

items.title: Back-end Engineer
details: Performed analytics on large geographic datasets from OpenStreetMap, GeoNames, and other sources.

items.title: Programming/Computer Science Tutor
details: Tutored two Stuyvesant High School students in computer-science for their CS 101 class over the span of six months.
Currently teaching a middle-school student how to program in Python.

items.headline: **bitshift**, a source-code search engine. <<bitshift.it>>
points: Helped develop _bitshift_, a search engine for source code published on various online frameworks (GitHub, Bitbucket, etc.). Allows users to search for language symbols, like loops and variables, and code metadata.
Will be presented at the Sep. 2014 **New York Tech Meetup**.

items.headline: **Tour de City**, a city-bike tour app. <<tour-de-city.com>>
points: Developed an application that allows users to generate tours to popular venues in various cities using bicycles from bike-share programs.
3<sup>rd</sup> place in the **US IEEE App competition**.
Semifinalist in the high-school division of MIT Media Lab's 2014 **Dream It. Code It. Win It.**.

items.headline: New website for the CSTUY organization. <<cstuy.org>>
points: Developed a new website for CSTUY, a non-profit that promotes computer-science education for high-school students.

items.headline: **stuybooks**, an application for literary quote submissions. <<stuybooks.com>>
points: Developed a web application that allows the submission of literary quotes to a public wall of text.

description: Built a rudimentary graphics engine from the ground up.
Started with per-pixel access, and implemented rasterization, polygonal rendering, z-buffering, shading, etc.
Miscellaneous personal projects, like algorithm implementations and experimentations with various languages.
My personal collection of dotfiles and system administration scripts.
